Title: 508: [Engagement Manager][Status][1.4.3]: Color contrast ratio failed for the "save" button under Points of Emphasis card in the status page.
Description: Please see Repro Steps field for bug details.
Repro Steps:
Screen reader: NVDA

URL Tested: Status

Test results:

5/28/2025 12:51 PM Bug filed on "Color - Text Contrast (1.4.3)"
Step no. Result Title
1. Failed

Run an automated color contrast check in axe or another tool if you haven't already, and manually validate the automated tool results if necessary, by using the TPGi Colour Contrast Analyser (CCA) or a similar manual color picker. Some examples of text that may pass automated validation and require a manual review are placeholder text within fields, text overlayed on a background image or video, or text within read-only inputs. Disabled controls are exempt from color contrast requirements.

Expected Result

Small Text: Text smaller than 24px (18pt) meets at least 4.5:1 contrast against its background. (1.4.3) Large Text: Text at least 19px (14pt) bold or 24px (18pt) non-bold meets at least 3:1 contrast against its background (1.4.3)

Comments: 

Summary:
The text in the "save" button under the Points of Emphasis card has insufficient color contrast, making it difficult to read for users with visual impairments.

Test environment:
Chrome Version: 137.0.7151.56 (Official Build) (64-bit)
Test URL: https://www.engagementmanager.thomsonreuters.com/

Steps to reproduce:
  1. Open the above URL and login with valid credentials.
  2. Navigate to the "open engagements" button and invoke it.
  3. Open any engagement from engagements list.
  4. Navigate to the "status" button from the left navigation list and invoke it.
  5. Locate the "Points of Emphasis" card.
  6. Click on add button and add anything.
  7. Observe the color contrast ratio for the "save" button.
Actual results:

Title: 508: [Engagement Manager][Trail balance][1.4.10]: Placeholder Text "Search Accounts" and "Search Description" Not Fully Visible at 400% Zoom.
Description: Please see Repro Steps field for bug details.
Repro Steps:
Screen reader: NVDA

URL Tested: Feature7

Test results:

5/28/2025 12:46 PM Bug filed on "Responsive and Reflow - 400% Resize (1.4.10)"
Step no. Result Title
1. Failed

Set the viewport width to 1280 CSS pixels wide and 1024 CSS pixels tall, and gradually increase page zoom up to 400%. Check page functionality and readability at each zoom increment between 100% and 400%. On complex sites, user may need to refresh, or browse to the page with resizing already applied, in order for the resizing to properly apply.

Expected Result

Content can be zoomed up to 400% without overlap, loss of functionality, or use of horizontal scrolling (tables and graphics excluded). (1.4.10) -Solutions must be considered for fixed/floating content on mobile views ("Pinned" or "Sticky" elements often overlaps/hides content at higher zoom levels and may need to scroll as a result) Information can be reorganized and user interface components can adapt at mobile breakpoints, provided information is not lost. (1.4.10) Do not truncate content vital to the understanding or meaning of the page unless there is an accessible way to view that content in full. (1.4.10)

Comments: 

Summary: 
At 400% zoom, the placeholder text "Search Accounts" and "Search Description" in the form fields is not completely visible. This issue affects users who require significant zoom levels to read text, compromising the accessibility

Test Environment:
Browser: Chrome version (134.0.6998.89)
Screen Reader: NVDA
URL: https://www.engagementmanager.thomsonreuters.com/Angular/#/Engagements/5203/TrialBalances

Pre-Requisite steps:
1. Set the viewport width to 1280 CSS pixels wide and 1024 CSS pixels tall, and gradually increase page zoom up to 400%.

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open the URL -  https://www.engagementmanager.thomsonreuters.com/
2. Login with Valid credentials
3. Engagement manager will be displayed.
4. Navigate to any link and click on it.
5. Activate "Trial Balance" in the left navigation.
6. Activate View -> Balance Definitions.
7. "Balance Definitions" page appears.
8. Activate checkboxes in the table.
9. Then activate "Select" below "Rounding Accounts" headings.
10. "Assign Account" modal appears.
11. Zoom the page to 400% and observe.

Actual Result: 
The placeholder text becomes truncated or obscured at 400% zoom, making it difficult for users to understand.

Expected Result:
Placeholder text should be fully visible at 400% zoom to ensure accessibility for users with visual impairments who rely on high zoom levels.

Note:  The same issues appears for remaining select buttons below "Rounding Accounts" headings.

Screenshot-2025-05-28T12-46-22.590Z.png

Run an automated color contrast check in axe or another tool if you haven't already, and manually validate the automated tool results if necessary, by using the TPGi Colour Contrast Analyser (CCA) or a similar manual color picker. Title: 508: [Engagement Manager][Properties][1.3.1]: Required field is not announced by screen reader for MASK Required field
Description: Please see Repro Steps field for bug details.
Repro Steps:
Screen reader: NVDA

URL Tested: https://www.engagementmanager.thomsonreuters.com/Angular/#/Engagements/5997418/Workpapers

Test results:

5/29/2025 5:49 AM Bug filed on "Screen Reader - NVDA - Information, Structure, and Relationship Information is Available (1.3.1)"
Step no. Result Title
1. None

User navigates page with the screen reader and verifies that list information is either correctly identified by the screen reader or available in text.

Expected Result

Bullets or numbered lists are identified as lists either by the screen reader recognizing them or in the associated text. (1.3.1) Content that is clearly not part of a list is not falsely identified as one. (1.3.1) When a list has been programmatically defined, the screen reader announces the correct number of items in the list (1.3.1) List items that appear in columns are coded as one continuous list and only styled to appear in columns. (1.3.1)

2. None

User navigates page with the screen reader using its browse function (up and down arrows for NVDA) and verifies that the screen reader correctly identifies table and grid information

Expected Result

Data tables correctly identified as tables by the screen reader (1.3.1) Data grids are correctly identified as grids by the screen reader (1.3.1) Any HTML tables used for layout have role="presentation". (1.3.1) The number of rows and columns in the table or grid is accurately conveyed to screen reader users. (1.3.1) The screen reader announces cell content as well as the new column or row header associated to the cell. (1.3.1)

3. None

User navigates any sortable table or grid with the screen reader using its browse function (up and down arrows for NVDA) and verifies that the screen reader correctly identifies sort functionality and state

Expected Result

The sorting control is a semantic button, built with <button> element or role="button". (1.3.1) The current sorting state (unsorted, ascending, descending) is conveyed visually and within the code (aria-sort="ascending/descending" attribute applied to the sorted column <th> element). (1.3.1, 4.1.2)

4. None

User navigates page with screen reader or inspects code and verifies that any text with meaningful text decoration (highlighting, strikethrough, insertion, bolding, emphasis, etc) is coded with the appropriate tags (<mark>, <del>, <ins>, <strong>, <em>, etc.) Note that most assistive technology will not announce bolding or italics in its default setting.

Expected Result

Semantic markup identifies emphasized or special text formatting. (1.3.1)

5. None

User navigates page with screen reader or inspects code and verifies that blockquotes are applied to visually blockquoted text

Expected Result

Blockquotes are identified as block quotes by the screen reader so that they are aware that this is quoted content (1.3.1) Blockquotes are not used for content that is not being quoted from another source (1.3.1)

6. Failed

User navigates pages with screen reader and verifies that any other information and relationships that are implied by visual formatting are available to the screen reader

Expected Result

Information, structure, and relationships conveyed through presentation can be programmatically determined or are available in text. (1.3.1)

Comments: Required field is not announced by screen reader for MASK Required field 
Url : https://www.engagementmanager.thomsonreuters.com/Angular/#/Engagements/5997418/Workpapers

Title: 508: [Engagement Manager][Communications][3.2.2]: Without user input radio button is going automatically unselected state
Description: Please see Repro Steps field for bug details.
Repro Steps:
Screen reader: NVDA

URL Tested: Communications

Test results:

5/29/2025 7:38 AM Bug filed on "Keyboard - No Change of Context on Input (3.2.2)"
Step no. Result Title
1. Failed

User changes the setting of a checkbox, selects a radio button, selects a list option in a form, or otherwise changes the setting of a user interface component. This test does not apply to buttons, links, or options within navigation dropdown menus.

Expected Result

Focus is not moved as a result of changing the value or setting of a component, unless the user is informed of that behavior beforehand. (3.2.2) Changing the value or setting of a component does not cause a substantial change to the page, unless the user has been advised ahead of time (e.g. a language selection dropdown with an appropriate label). (3.2.2)

Test Environment:
Application: Engagement Manager (Communications)
Browser: Chrome

URL: https://www.engagementmanager.thomsonreuters.com/Angular/#/Engagements/5997393/Communications

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open the above URL in chrome browser and login with valid credentials.
2. Activate the "communications" link from left navigation.
3. Navigate to the 'create request' dropdown and select 'create new request from template' control.
4. 'Create from template' dialog will appear.
5. Navigate to the radio button and try to select it any of them.
6. Again navigate to the 'search template' edit box with tab key or shift tab key while radio button in selected state and observe the behavior of radio button.

Actual results:
Radio button is going to automatically in unselected state, when the keyboard focus lands on 'search template' edit box with tab key or shift tab key.

Expected results:
Radio button should not go to automatically in unselected state without any user input to radio button.

Title: 508: [Engagement Manager][Trail balance][4.1.3]: Loading Indicator in "Assign Account" Modal Is Not Automatically Announced
Description: Please see Repro Steps field for bug details.
Repro Steps:
Screen reader: NVDA

URL Tested: Feature7

Test results:

5/29/2025 9:32 AM Bug filed on "Screen Reader - NVDA - Status Messages (4.1.3)"
Step no. Result Title
1. Failed

User triggers any status message (text or image based) that informs them that something is successful, loading, in progress, has errored, or that they have been logged out

Expected Result

Status updates (success, loading, in progress, error states, or logout notifications) that occur on the same page and do not receive focus are announced using aria-live or a role with implicit aria-live (status, log, progressbar). (4.1.3)

Comments: 

Summary: When the user activates the "Select" button, the "Assign Account" modal appears with a loading indicator. However, the loading indicator is not automatically announced, which may affect accessibility for users relying on screen readers.

Test Environment:
Browser: Chrome version (134.0.6998.89)
ScreenReader: NVDA
URL: https://www.engagementmanager.thomsonreuters.com/Angular/#/Engagements/5203/TrialBalances

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open the URL -  https://www.engagementmanager.thomsonreuters.com/
2. Login with Valid credentials
3. Engagement manager will be displayed.
4. Navigate to any link and click on it.
5. Activate "Trial Balance" in the left navigation.
6. Activate View -> Balance Definitions.
7. "Balance Definitions" page appears.
8. Activate checkboxes in the table.
9. Then activate "Select" below "Rounding Accounts" headings.
10. "Assign Account" modal appears. Now check whether loading indicator is automatically announced or not.

Actual Result: 
The loading indicator is not automatically announced, potentially causing accessibility issues.
Expected Result:
The loading indicator should be automatically announced to ensure accessibility for users utilizing screen readers.

Title: 508: [Engagement Manager][Workpapers][1.3.1]: Table markup is not defined correctly.
Description: Please see Repro Steps field for bug details.
Repro Steps:
Screen reader: NVDA

URL Tested: Feature6

Test results:

5/31/2025 8:51 AM Bug filed on "Screen Reader - NVDA - Information, Structure, and Relationship Information is Available (1.3.1)"
Step no. Result Title
1. None

User navigates page with the screen reader and verifies that list information is either correctly identified by the screen reader or available in text.

Expected Result

Bullets or numbered lists are identified as lists either by the screen reader recognizing them or in the associated text. (1.3.1) Content that is clearly not part of a list is not falsely identified as one. (1.3.1) When a list has been programmatically defined, the screen reader announces the correct number of items in the list (1.3.1) List items that appear in columns are coded as one continuous list and only styled to appear in columns. (1.3.1)

2. Failed

User navigates page with the screen reader using its browse function (up and down arrows for NVDA) and verifies that the screen reader correctly identifies table and grid information

Expected Result

Data tables correctly identified as tables by the screen reader (1.3.1) Data grids are correctly identified as grids by the screen reader (1.3.1) Any HTML tables used for layout have role="presentation". (1.3.1) The number of rows and columns in the table or grid is accurately conveyed to screen reader users. (1.3.1) The screen reader announces cell content as well as the new column or row header associated to the cell. (1.3.1)

Comments: 
Summary:
Users who rely on screen reader will find difficulty because treegrid table is not defined correctly.

Test Environment:
Browser: Chrome
URL: https://www.engagementmanager.thomsonreuters.com/Angular/#/Engagements/5986393/Workpapers
Screen reader: NVDA

Repro Steps:
1. Open the above URL in chrome browser using valid login credentials.
2. Engagement Manager home page will be displayed.
3. Navigate to any engagement record link and click on it.
4. Navigate to Workpapers section and click on it.
5. Workpapers page will be displayed.
6. Navigate to table elements using TAB or arrow keys.
7. veirfy whether the table markup is defined correctly or not.

Actual Result:
Table markup is not defined correctly.

Observation: treegrid structure is not defined correctly for the table elements. NVDA is narrating the unnecessary information while arrow and TAB key.

Expected Result:
table markup should be defined correctly.

Reference: https://www.w3.org/WAI/ARIA/apg/patterns/treegrid/examples/treegrid-1/

3. None

User navigates any sortable table or grid with the screen reader using its browse function (up and down arrows for NVDA) and verifies that the screen reader correctly identifies sort functionality and state

Expected Result

The sorting control is a semantic button, built with <button> element or role="button". (1.3.1) The current sorting state (unsorted, ascending, descending) is conveyed visually and within the code (aria-sort="ascending/descending" attribute applied to the sorted column <th> element). (1.3.1, 4.1.2)

4. None

User navigates page with screen reader or inspects code and verifies that any text with meaningful text decoration (highlighting, strikethrough, insertion, bolding, emphasis, etc) is coded with the appropriate tags (<mark>, <del>, <ins>, <strong>, <em>, etc.) Note that most assistive technology will not announce bolding or italics in its default setting.

Expected Result

Semantic markup identifies emphasized or special text formatting. (1.3.1)

5. None

User navigates page with screen reader or inspects code and verifies that blockquotes are applied to visually blockquoted text

Expected Result

Blockquotes are identified as block quotes by the screen reader so that they are aware that this is quoted content (1.3.1) Blockquotes are not used for content that is not being quoted from another source (1.3.1)

6. None

User navigates pages with screen reader and verifies that any other information and relationships that are implied by visual formatting are available to the screen reader

Expected Result

Information, structure, and relationships conveyed through presentation can be programmatically determined or are available in text. (1.3.1)

URL Tested: Feature6

Test results:

6/1/2025 1:17 AM Bug filed on "Screen Reader - NVDA - Labels and Instructions are Associated (1.3.1)"
Step no. Result Title
1. Failed

User navigates page with screen reader and for each input element verifies that any instructions, labels, and legends are associated with their fields and read correctly by the screen reader

Expected Result

All inputs in a form are programmatically associated with a corresponding descriptive label element. (1.3.1) Additional instructions or “help text” for the input are programmatically associated with the input element. (1.3.1) Short (2-3 word) formatting or helper instructions for the field should be included in the <label> element. (TR Ideal) Longer instructional "help text" for a form field must be associated to the field by setting the <input> aria-describedby attribute to the value of the help text element’s id attribute. If a form element is required and that cannot be assumed from page context, it either includes this information in the label, or has the "required" attribute in its tag. (1.3.1) Groups of form elements, such as radio buttons or checkboxes, are semantically associated with the group description. (1.3.1, 3.3.2)

Users who rely on screen reader will find difficulty because label is not defined for the edit field.

Title: 508: [Engagement Manager][Workpapers][2.4.3]: Focus is not landing on the dialog heading or first interactive element close button once the dialog is displayed.
Description: Please see Repro Steps field for bug details.
Repro Steps:
Screen reader: NVDA

URL Tested: Feature6

Test results:

6/1/2025 1:26 AM Bug filed on "Keyboard - Focus Order During Operation (2.4.3)"
Step no. Result Title
1. None

User interacts with any components that move the page viewport (e.g. activating a link to a footnote within the page)

Expected Result

Same-page links move both viewport and focus to the expected location. (2.4.3)

2. None

User interacts with any element that dynamically loads search results

Expected Result

For dynamically loaded search results, focus remains on the search control that initiated the search action. (2.4.3) For search results that populate on page reload, the focus resets to the top of the page.

3. Failed

User interacts with any components that trigger a dialog

Expected Result

When a dialog is opened, focus moves to a logical place within the dialog. (2.4.3) Visible and keyboard focus is constrained to open modal dialogs. (2.4.3) Visible and keyboard focus is not constrained to open non-modal dialogs. (2.4.3) When a dialog is dismissed, closed, or collapsed, focus moves back to the trigger control. (2.4.3)

Comments: 
Summary:
Users who rely on screen reader will find difficulty because focus is not landing on the dialog heading or first interactive element close button once the dialog is displayed.

Test Environment:
Browser: Chrome
URL: https://www.engagementmanager.thomsonreuters.com/Angular/#/Engagements/5986393/Workpapers
Screen reader: NVDA

Repro Steps:
1. Open the above URL in chrome browser using valid login credentials.
2. Engagement Manager home page will be displayed.
3. Navigate to any engagement record link and click on it.
4. Navigate to Workpapers section and click on it.
5. Workpapers page will be displayed.
6. Navigate to Add button and expand it.
7. Navigate to folder element and click on it.
8. Dialog will be displayed.
9. Verify whether the focus is landing on dialog heading or not.

Actual Result:
Focus is not landing on the dialog heading or first interactive element close button once the dialog is displayed.

When a dialog appears, visible focus is set to the dialog heading. However, the dialog heading is not added to the tab order.

Note: Same issue observed in through out the Workpapers section and notes list page.


Actual Result:
Focus should be land on the dialog heading or first interactive element close button once the dialog is displayed.
Attachment(s):
Screenshot-2025-06-01T01-25-42.610Z.png
4. None

User interacts with any components that are removed once triggered

Expected Result

When the currently focused element is removed from the page, focus is moved to a logical location (e.g., next or previous element, section heading, or triggering control). (2.4.3)

5. None

User activates any buttons that sort tables

Expected Result

After a user activates the sorting button, keyboard focus remains on the button. (2.4.3)

Title: 508: [Engagement Manager][Workpapers][1.3.1]: Unnecessary table is defined in the list.
Description: Please see Repro Steps field for bug details.
Repro Steps:
Screen reader: NVDA

URL Tested: Feature6

Test results:

6/1/2025 2:30 AM Bug filed on "Screen Reader - NVDA - Information, Structure, and Relationship Information is Available (1.3.1)"
Step no. Result Title
1. Failed

User navigates page with the screen reader and verifies that list information is either correctly identified by the screen reader or available in text.

Expected Result

Bullets or numbered lists are identified as lists either by the screen reader recognizing them or in the associated text. (1.3.1) Content that is clearly not part of a list is not falsely identified as one. (1.3.1) When a list has been programmatically defined, the screen reader announces the correct number of items in the list (1.3.1) List items that appear in columns are coded as one continuous list and only styled to appear in columns. (1.3.1)

Comments:
 Summary:
Users who rely on screen reader will find difficulty because unnecessary table markup is defined in the list.

Test Environment:
Browser: Chrome
URL: https://www.engagementmanager.thomsonreuters.com/Angular/#/Engagements/5986393/Workpapers
Screen reader: NVDA

Repro Steps:
1. Open the above URL in chrome browser using valid login credentials.
2. Engagement Manager home page will be displayed.
3. Navigate to any engagement record link and click on it.
4. Navigate to Workpapers section and click on it.
5. Workpapers page will be displayed.
6. Navigate to Add button and expand it.
7. Navigate to Note element and click on it.
8. Dialog will be displayed.
9. Navigate to combo boxes using TAB Key and expand it.
10. Navigate to list elements using arrow keys.
11. Verify whether the list markup is defined correctly or not.

Actual Result:
Unnecessary table is defined in the list.

Observation: NVDA is narrating unnecessary table when navigating to the list.
Same issue observed for the status and Assigned to combo boxes.

Note: Same issue observed in through out the Workpapers section and notes list page.

Expected Result:
Unnecessary table should be removed from the list.
Attachment(s):
Screenshot-2025-06-01T02-29-56.969Z.png
2. None

User navigates page with the screen reader using its browse function (up and down arrows for NVDA) and verifies that the screen reader correctly identifies table and grid information

Expected Result

Data tables correctly identified as tables by the screen reader (1.3.1) Data grids are correctly identified as grids by the screen reader (1.3.1) Any HTML tables used for layout have role="presentation". (1.3.1) The number of rows and columns in the table or grid is accurately conveyed to screen reader users. (1.3.1) The screen reader announces cell content as well as the new column or row header associated to the cell. (1.3.1)

3. None

User navigates any sortable table or grid with the screen reader using its browse function (up and down arrows for NVDA) and verifies that the screen reader correctly identifies sort functionality and state

Expected Result

The sorting control is a semantic button, built with <button> element or role="button". (1.3.1) The current sorting state (unsorted, ascending, descending) is conveyed visually and within the code (aria-sort="ascending/descending" attribute applied to the sorted column <th> element). (1.3.1, 4.1.2)

4. None

User navigates page with screen reader or inspects code and verifies that any text with meaningful text decoration (highlighting, strikethrough, insertion, bolding, emphasis, etc) is coded with the appropriate tags (<mark>, <del>, <ins>, <strong>, <em>, etc.) Note that most assistive technology will not announce bolding or italics in its default setting.

Expected Result

Semantic markup identifies emphasized or special text formatting. (1.3.1)

5. None

User navigates page with screen reader or inspects code and verifies that blockquotes are applied to visually blockquoted text

Expected Result

Blockquotes are identified as block quotes by the screen reader so that they are aware that this is quoted content (1.3.1) Blockquotes are not used for content that is not being quoted from another source (1.3.1)

6. None

User navigates pages with screen reader and verifies that any other information and relationships that are implied by visual formatting are available to the screen reader

Expected Result

Information, structure, and relationships conveyed through presentation can be programmatically determined or are available in text. (1.3.1)

Title: 508: [Engagement Manager][Workpapers][1.3.1]: Label name is not defined for the edit field.
Description: Please see Repro Steps field for bug details.
Repro Steps:
Screen reader: NVDA

URL Tested: Feature6

Test results:

6/1/2025 2:51 AM Bug filed on "Screen Reader - NVDA - Labels and Instructions are Associated (1.3.1)"
Step no. Result Title
1. Failed

User navigates page with screen reader and for each input element verifies that any instructions, labels, and legends are associated with their fields and read correctly by the screen reader

Expected Result

All inputs in a form are programmatically associated with a corresponding descriptive label element. (1.3.1) Additional instructions or “help text” for the input are programmatically associated with the input element. (1.3.1) Short (2-3 word) formatting or helper instructions for the field should be included in the <label> element. (TR Ideal) Longer instructional "help text" for a form field must be associated to the field by setting the <input> aria-describedby attribute to the value of the help text element’s id attribute. If a form element is required and that cannot be assumed from page context, it either includes this information in the label, or has the "required" attribute in its tag. (1.3.1) Groups of form elements, such as radio buttons or checkboxes, are semantically associated with the group description. (1.3.1, 3.3.2)

Comments: 
Summary:
Users who rely on screen reader will find difficulty because label name is not defined for the edit field.

Test Environment:
Browser: Chrome
URL: https://www.engagementmanager.thomsonreuters.com/Angular/#/Engagements/5986393/Workpapers
Screen reader: NVDA

3. Navigate to any engagement record link and click on it.
4. Navigate to Workpapers section and click on it.
5. Workpapers page will be displayed.
6. Navigate to Add button and expand it.
7. Navigate to Note element and click on it.
8. Dialog will be displayed.
9. Navigate to edit field using TAB key.
10. Verify whether the label name is defined for the edit field or not.

Actual Result:
Label name is not defined for the edit field.
Note: Same issue observed in through out the Workpapers section and notes list page.

Expected Result:
Label name should be defined for the edit field.

Title: 508: [Engagement Manager][Workpapers][2.4.3]: After remove the attachment Focus is not moves back to the browse for file button.

URL Tested: Feature6

Test results:

6/1/2025 12:56 PM Bug filed on "Keyboard - Focus Order During Operation (2.4.3)"
Step no. Result Title
1. None

User interacts with any components that move the page viewport (e.g. activating a link to a footnote within the page)

Expected Result

Same-page links move both viewport and focus to the expected location. (2.4.3)

2. None

User interacts with any element that dynamically loads search results

Expected Result

For dynamically loaded search results, focus remains on the search control that initiated the search action. (2.4.3) For search results that populate on page reload, the focus resets to the top of the page.

3. None

User interacts with any components that trigger a dialog

Expected Result

When a dialog is opened, focus moves to a logical place within the dialog. (2.4.3) Visible and keyboard focus is constrained to open modal dialogs. (2.4.3) Visible and keyboard focus is not constrained to open non-modal dialogs. (2.4.3) When a dialog is dismissed, closed, or collapsed, focus moves back to the trigger control. (2.4.3)

4. Failed

User interacts with any components that are removed once triggered

When the currently focused element is removed from the page, focus is moved to a logical location (e.g., next or previous element, section heading, or triggering control). (2.4.3)

Users who rely on keyboard navigation will find difficulty because after removing the attachment focus is not move back to browse for file button.

Title: 508: [Engagement Manager][Workpapers][1.3.1]: Checkboxes are not grouped.
Description: Please see Repro Steps field for bug details.
Repro Steps:
Screen reader: NVDA

URL Tested: Feature6

Test results:

6/1/2025 2:28 PM Bug filed on "Screen Reader - NVDA - Labels and Instructions are Associated (1.3.1)"
Step no. Result Title
1. Failed

User navigates page with screen reader and for each input element verifies that any instructions, labels, and legends are associated with their fields and read correctly by the screen reader

Expected Result

All inputs in a form are programmatically associated with a corresponding descriptive label element. (1.3.1) Additional instructions or “help text” for the input are programmatically associated with the input element. (1.3.1) Short (2-3 word) formatting or helper instructions for the field should be included in the <label> element. (TR Ideal) Longer instructional "help text" for a form field must be associated to the field by setting the <input> aria-describedby attribute to the value of the help text element’s id attribute. If a form element is required and that cannot be assumed from page context, it either includes this information in the label, or has the "required" attribute in its tag. (1.3.1) Groups of form elements, such as radio buttons or checkboxes, are semantically associated with the group description. (1.3.1, 3.3.2)

Comments: 
Summary:
Users who rely on screen reader will find difficulty because checkboxes are not grouped.

Test Environment:
Browser: Chrome
URL: https://www.engagementmanager.thomsonreuters.com/Angular/#/Engagements/5986393/Workpapers
Screen reader: NVDA

Repro Steps:
1. Open the above URL in chrome browser using valid login credentials.
2. Engagement Manager home page will be displayed.
3. Navigate to any engagement record link and click on it.
4. Navigate to Workpapers section and click on it.
5. Workpapers page will be displayed.
6. Navigate to Add button and expand it.
7. Navigate to workpaper element and click on it.
8. Dialog will be displayed. Select Go file room in the combo box.
9. Navigate to next button and click on it.
10. New page will be displayed.
11. Navigate to checkboxes using TAB Key.
12. Verify whether the checkboxes are grouped or not.

Actual Result:
Checkboxes are not grouped.

Note: Same issue observed in through out the Workpapers section and notes list page.

Expected Result:
fieldset, legend attribute should be removed for the checkboxes.
Attachment(s):
Screenshot-2025-06-01T14-28-02.365Z.png
Test Configuration: Demo AF

Reference links:https://trten.sharepoint.com/sites/intr-digital-accessibility-coe/SitePages/Form.aspx

Title: 508: [Engagement Manager][Workpapers][1.3.1]: Unable to access the table elements using keyboard.
Description: Please see Repro Steps field for bug details.
Repro Steps:
Screen reader: NVDA

URL Tested: Feature6

Test results:

6/1/2025 2:42 PM Bug filed on "Screen Reader - NVDA - Information, Structure, and Relationship Information is Available (1.3.1)"
Step no. Result Title
1. Failed

User navigates page with the screen reader and verifies that list information is either correctly identified by the screen reader or available in text.

Expected Result

Bullets or numbered lists are identified as lists either by the screen reader recognizing them or in the associated text. (1.3.1) Content that is clearly not part of a list is not falsely identified as one. (1.3.1) When a list has been programmatically defined, the screen reader announces the correct number of items in the list (1.3.1) List items that appear in columns are coded as one continuous list and only styled to appear in columns. (1.3.1)

Comments: 
Summary:
Users who rely on screen reader will find difficulty because unable to access the table elements using keyboard.

Test Environment:
Browser: Chrome
URL: https://www.engagementmanager.thomsonreuters.com/Angular/#/Engagements/5986393/Workpapers
Screen reader: NVDA

Repro Steps:
1. Open the above URL in chrome browser using valid login credentials.
2. Engagement Manager home page will be displayed.
3. Navigate to any engagement record link and click on it.
4. Navigate to Workpapers section and click on it.
5. Workpapers page will be displayed.
6. Navigate to Add button and expand it.
7. Navigate to workpaper element and click on it.
8. Dialog will be displayed. Select Go to file room in the combo box.
9. Navigate to next button and click on it.
10. New page will be displayed.
11. Navigate to table elements using TAB key.
12. Verify whether the table elements are accessible or not.

Expected Result:
User should be able to access the table elements using keyboard.
Attachment(s):
Screenshot-2025-06-01T14-41-49.608Z.png
2. None

User navigates page with the screen reader using its browse function (up and down arrows for NVDA) and verifies that the screen reader correctly identifies table and grid information

Expected Result

Data tables correctly identified as tables by the screen reader (1.3.1) Data grids are correctly identified as grids by the screen reader (1.3.1) Any HTML tables used for layout have role="presentation". (1.3.1) The number of rows and columns in the table or grid is accurately conveyed to screen reader users. (1.3.1) The screen reader announces cell content as well as the new column or row header associated to the cell. (1.3.1)

3. None

User navigates any sortable table or grid with the screen reader using its browse function (up and down arrows for NVDA) and verifies that the screen reader correctly identifies sort functionality and state

Expected Result

The sorting control is a semantic button, built with <button> element or role="button". (1.3.1) The current sorting state (unsorted, ascending, descending) is conveyed visually and within the code (aria-sort="ascending/descending" attribute applied to the sorted column <th> element). (1.3.1, 4.1.2)

4. None

User navigates page with screen reader or inspects code and verifies that any text with meaningful text decoration (highlighting, strikethrough, insertion, bolding, emphasis, etc) is coded with the appropriate tags (<mark>, <del>, <ins>, <strong>, <em>, etc.) Note that most assistive technology will not announce bolding or italics in its default setting.

Expected Result

Semantic markup identifies emphasized or special text formatting. (1.3.1)

5. None

User navigates page with screen reader or inspects code and verifies that blockquotes are applied to visually blockquoted text

Expected Result

Blockquotes are identified as block quotes by the screen reader so that they are aware that this is quoted content (1.3.1) Blockquotes are not used for content that is not being quoted from another source (1.3.1)

6. None

User navigates pages with screen reader and verifies that any other information and relationships that are implied by visual formatting are available to the screen reader

Expected Result

Information, structure, and relationships conveyed through presentation can be programmatically determined or are available in text. (1.3.1)

Step no. Result Title
1. Failed

User navigates page with screen reader and for each input element verifies that any instructions, labels, and legends are associated with their fields and read correctly by the screen reader

Expected Result

All inputs in a form are programmatically associated with a corresponding descriptive label element. (1.3.1) Additional instructions or “help text” for the input are programmatically associated with the input element. (1.3.1) Short (2-3 word) formatting or helper instructions for the field should be included in the <label> element. URL Tested: Feature6

6/2/2025 1:28 AM Bug filed on "Screen Reader - NVDA - Information, Structure, and Relationship Information is Available (1.3.1)"
Step no. Result Title
1. Failed

User navigates page with the screen reader and verifies that list information is either correctly identified by the screen reader or available in text.

Expected Result

Bullets or numbered lists are identified as lists either by the screen reader recognizing them or in the associated text. (1.3.1) Content that is clearly not part of a list is not falsely identified as one. (1.3.1) When a list has been programmatically defined, the screen reader announces the correct number of items in the list (1.3.1) List items that appear in columns are coded as one continuous list and only styled to appear in columns. (1.3.1)

Comments: 
Summary:
Users who rely on screen reader will find difficulty because Screen reader narrating the incorrect number of items in the list.

Test Environment:
Browser: Chrome
URL: https://www.engagementmanager.thomsonreuters.com/Angular/#/Engagements/5986393/Workpapers
Screen reader: NVDA

Repro Steps:
1. Open the above URL in chrome browser using valid login credentials.
2. Engagement Manager home page will be displayed.
3. Navigate to any engagement record link and click on it.
4. Navigate to Workpapers section and click on it.

Screenshot-2025-06-02T01-27-40.050Z.png
2. None

User navigates page with the screen reader using its browse function (up and down arrows for NVDA) and verifies that the screen reader correctly identifies table and grid information

Expected Result

Data tables correctly identified as tables by the screen reader (1.3.1) Data grids are correctly identified as grids by the screen reader (1.3.1) Any HTML tables used for layout have role="presentation". (1.3.1) The number of rows and columns in the table or grid is accurately conveyed to screen reader users. (1.3.1) The screen reader announces cell content as well as the new column or row header associated to the cell. (1.3.1)

3. None

User navigates any sortable table or grid with the screen reader using its browse function (up and down arrows for NVDA) and verifies that the screen reader correctly identifies sort functionality and state

Expected Result

The sorting control is a semantic button, built with <button> element or role="button". (1.3.1) The current sorting state (unsorted, ascending, descending) is conveyed visually and within the code (aria-sort="ascending/descending" attribute applied to the sorted column <th> element). (1.3.1, 4.1.2)

4. None

User navigates page with screen reader or inspects code and verifies that any text with meaningful text decoration (highlighting, strikethrough, insertion, bolding, emphasis, etc) is coded with the appropriate tags (<mark>, <del>, <ins>, <strong>, <em>, etc.) Note that most assistive technology will not announce bolding or italics in its default setting.

Expected Result

Semantic markup identifies emphasized or special text formatting. (1.3.1)

5. None

User navigates page with screen reader or inspects code and verifies that blockquotes are applied to visually blockquoted text

Expected Result

Blockquotes are identified as block quotes by the screen reader so that they are aware that this is quoted content (1.3.1) Blockquotes are not used for content that is not being quoted from another source (1.3.1)

6. None

User navigates pages with screen reader and verifies that any other information and relationships that are implied by visual formatting are available to the screen reader

Title: 508: [Engagement Manager][Workpapers][1.3.1]: Radio buttons are not grouped.
Description: Please see Repro Steps field for bug details.
Repro Steps:
Screen reader: NVDA

URL Tested: Feature6

Test results:

6/2/2025 1:33 AM Bug filed on "Screen Reader - NVDA - Labels and Instructions are Associated (1.3.1)"
Step no. Result Title
1. Failed

User navigates page with screen reader and for each input element verifies that any instructions, labels, and legends are associated with their fields and read correctly by the screen reader

Expected Result

All inputs in a form are programmatically associated with a corresponding descriptive label element. (1.3.1) Additional instructions or “help text” for the input are programmatically associated with the input element. (1.3.1) Short (2-3 word) formatting or helper instructions for the field should be included in the <label> element. (TR Ideal) Longer instructional "help text" for a form field must be associated to the field by setting the <input> aria-describedby attribute to the value of the help text element’s id attribute. If a form element is required and that cannot be assumed from page context, it either includes this information in the label, or has the "required" attribute in its tag. (1.3.1) Groups of form elements, such as radio buttons or checkboxes, are semantically associated with the group description. (1.3.1, 3.3.2)

Comments: 
Summary:
Users who rely on screen reader will find difficulty because radio buttons are not grouped.

Browser: Chrome
URL: https://www.engagementmanager.thomsonreuters.com/Angular/#/Engagements/5986393/Workpapers

Title: 508: [Engagement Manager][Workpapers][2.4.3]: Focus is not landing on the first interactive element close button once the dialog is displayed.
Description: Please see Repro Steps field for bug details.
Repro Steps:
Screen reader: NVDA

URL Tested: Feature6

Test results:

6/3/2025 3:55 AM Bug filed on "Screen Reader - NVDA - Focus Order During Operation (2.4.3)"
Step no. Result Title
1. None

User interacts with any components that move the page viewport (e.g. activating a link to a footnote within the page)

Expected Result

Same-page links move both viewport and focus to the expected location. (2.4.3)

2. None

User interacts with any element that dynamically loads search results

Expected Result

For dynamically loaded search results, focus remains on the search control that initiated the search action. (2.4.3) For search results that populate on page reload, the focus resets to the top of the page.

3. Failed

User interacts with any components that trigger a dialog

Expected Result

When a dialog is opened, focus moves to a logical place within the dialog. (2.4.3) Visible and keyboard focus is constrained to open modal dialogs. (2.4.3) Visible and keyboard focus is not constrained to open non-modal dialogs. (2.4.3) When a dialog is dismissed, closed, or collapsed, focus moves back to the trigger control. (2.4.3)

Comments: 
Summary:
Users who rely on screen reader will find difficulty because Focus is not landing on the first interactive element close and not narrating dialog information once the dialog is displayed.

Test Environment:
Browser: Chrome
URL: https://www.engagementmanager.thomsonreuters.com/Angular/#/Engagements/5986393/Workpapers
Screen reader: NVDA

Repro Steps:
1. Open the above URL in chrome browser using valid login credentials.
2. Engagement Manager home page will be displayed.
3. Navigate to any engagement record link and click on it.
4. Navigate to setup panel button using TAB key and click on it.
5. Dialog will be displayed.
6. Verify whether the focus is landing on first interactive element or not.

Actual Result:
Focus is not landing on the first interactive element close button once the dialog is displayed.

Observation: NVDA is not narrating any dialog information and focus is not landing on any dialog element.

Expected Result:
Focus should be land on the first interactive element close button once the dialog is displayed.
Attachment(s):
Screenshot-2025-06-03T03-54-59.314Z.png
4. None

User interacts with any components that are removed once triggered

Expected Result

When the currently focused element is removed from the page, focus is moved to a logical location (e.g., next or previous element, section heading, or triggering control). (2.4.3)

5. None

User activates any buttons that sort tables

Expected Result

After a user activates the sorting button, keyboard focus remains on the button. (2.4.3)

Title: 508: [Engagement Manager][Setup panel][1.3.1]: List markup is not defined for the elements in the dialog.
Description: Please see Repro Steps field for bug details.
Repro Steps:
Screen reader: NVDA

URL Tested: Feature6

Test results:

6/3/2025 4:13 AM Bug filed on "Screen Reader - NVDA - Information, Structure, and Relationship Information is Available (1.3.1)"
Step no. Result Title
1. Failed

User navigates page with the screen reader and verifies that list information is either correctly identified by the screen reader or available in text.

Expected Result

Bullets or numbered lists are identified as lists either by the screen reader recognizing them or in the associated text. (1.3.1) Content that is clearly not part of a list is not falsely identified as one. (1.3.1) When a list has been programmatically defined, the screen reader announces the correct number of items in the list (1.3.1) List items that appear in columns are coded as one continuous list and only styled to appear in columns. (1.3.1)

Comments: 
Summary:
Users who rely on screen reader will find difficulty because list markup is not defined for the elements in the dialog.

Test Environment:
Browser: Chrome
URL: https://www.engagementmanager.thomsonreuters.com/Angular/#/Engagements/5986393/Workpapers
Screen reader: NVDA

Repro Steps:
1. Open the above URL in chrome browser using valid login credentials.
2. Engagement Manager home page will be displayed.
3. Navigate to any engagement record link and click on it.
4. Navigate to Workpapers section and click on it.
4. Navigate to Setup panel button and click on it.
5. Dialog will be displayed.
6. Verify whether the list markup is defined or not.

Actual Result:
List markup is not defined for the elements in the dialog.

Expected Result:
List markup should be defined for the elements in the dialog.
Attachment(s):
Screenshot-2025-06-03T04-12-42.509Z.png
2. None

User navigates page with the screen reader using its browse function (up and down arrows for NVDA) and verifies that the screen reader correctly identifies table and grid information

Expected Result

Data tables correctly identified as tables by the screen reader (1.3.1) Data grids are correctly identified as grids by the screen reader (1.3.1) Any HTML tables used for layout have role="presentation". (1.3.1) The number of rows and columns in the table or grid is accurately conveyed to screen reader users. (1.3.1) The screen reader announces cell content as well as the new column or row header associated to the cell. (1.3.1)

3. None

User navigates any sortable table or grid with the screen reader using its browse function (up and down arrows for NVDA) and verifies that the screen reader correctly identifies sort functionality and state

Expected Result

The sorting control is a semantic button, built with <button> element or role="button". (1.3.1) The current sorting state (unsorted, ascending, descending) is conveyed visually and within the code (aria-sort="ascending/descending" attribute applied to the sorted column <th> element). (1.3.1, 4.1.2)

4. None

User navigates page with screen reader or inspects code and verifies that any text with meaningful text decoration (highlighting, strikethrough, insertion, bolding, emphasis, etc) is coded with the appropriate tags (<mark>, <del>, <ins>, <strong>, <em>, etc.) Note that most assistive technology will not announce bolding or italics in its default setting.

Expected Result

Semantic markup identifies emphasized or special text formatting. (1.3.1)

5. None

User navigates page with screen reader or inspects code and verifies that blockquotes are applied to visually blockquoted text

Expected Result

Blockquotes are identified as block quotes by the screen reader so that they are aware that this is quoted content (1.3.1) Blockquotes are not used for content that is not being quoted from another source (1.3.1)

6. None

User navigates pages with screen reader and verifies that any other information and relationships that are implied by visual formatting are available to the screen reader

Expected Result

Information, structure, and relationships conveyed through presentation can be programmatically determined or are available in text. (1.3.1)

Title: 508: [Engagement Manager][Workpapers][1.3.1]: Aria sort attribute is not defined for the table headers.
Description: Please see Repro Steps field for bug details.
Repro Steps:
Screen reader: NVDA

URL Tested: Feature6

Test results:

6/3/2025 6:30 AM Bug filed on "Screen Reader - NVDA - Information, Structure, and Relationship Information is Available (1.3.1)"
Step no. Result Title
1. None

User navigates page with the screen reader and verifies that list information is either correctly identified by the screen reader or available in text.

Expected Result

Bullets or numbered lists are identified as lists either by the screen reader recognizing them or in the associated text. (1.3.1) Content that is clearly not part of a list is not falsely identified as one. (1.3.1) When a list has been programmatically defined, the screen reader announces the correct number of items in the list (1.3.1) List items that appear in columns are coded as one continuous list and only styled to appear in columns. (1.3.1)

2. None

User navigates page with the screen reader using its browse function (up and down arrows for NVDA) and verifies that the screen reader correctly identifies table and grid information

Expected Result

Data tables correctly identified as tables by the screen reader (1.3.1) Data grids are correctly identified as grids by the screen reader (1.3.1) Any HTML tables used for layout have role="presentation". (1.3.1) The number of rows and columns in the table or grid is accurately conveyed to screen reader users. (1.3.1) The screen reader announces cell content as well as the new column or row header associated to the cell. (1.3.1)

3. Failed

User navigates any sortable table or grid with the screen reader using its browse function (up and down arrows for NVDA) and verifies that the screen reader correctly identifies sort functionality and state

Expected Result

The sorting control is a semantic button, built with <button> element or role="button". (1.3.1) The current sorting state (unsorted, ascending, descending) is conveyed visually and within the code (aria-sort="ascending/descending" attribute applied to the sorted column <th> element). (1.3.1, 4.1.2)

Comments: 
Summary:
Users who rely on Screen reader will find difficulty because aria sort attribute is not defined for the sorting elements in the table and drag and drop element.

Test Environment:
Browser: Chrome
URL: https://www.engagementmanager.thomsonreuters.com/Angular/#/Engagements/5986393/Workpapers
Screen reader: NVDA

Repro Steps:
1. Open the above URL in chrome browser using valid login credentials.
2. Engagement Manager home page will be displayed.
3. Navigate to any engagement record link and click on it.
4. Navigate to Workpapers section and click on it.
5. drag the reference column from the table and click on it.
6. verify whether the aria- sort attribute is defined or not.

Actual Result:
Aria sort attribute is not defined for the table headers.

Expected Result:
Aria sort attribute should be defined for the table headers. NVDA should narrate the sorting state ascending and descending.
Attachment(s):
Screenshot-2025-06-03T06-29-51.651Z.png
4. None

User navigates page with screen reader or inspects code and verifies that any text with meaningful text decoration (highlighting, strikethrough, insertion, bolding, emphasis, etc) is coded with the appropriate tags (<mark>, <del>, <ins>, <strong>, <em>, etc.) Note that most assistive technology will not announce bolding or italics in its default setting.

Expected Result

Semantic markup identifies emphasized or special text formatting. (1.3.1)

5. None

User navigates page with screen reader or inspects code and verifies that blockquotes are applied to visually blockquoted text

Expected Result

Blockquotes are identified as block quotes by the screen reader so that they are aware that this is quoted content (1.3.1) Blockquotes are not used for content that is not being quoted from another source (1.3.1)

6. None

User navigates pages with screen reader and verifies that any other information and relationships that are implied by visual formatting are available to the screen reader

Expected Result

Information, structure, and relationships conveyed through presentation can be programmatically determined or are available in text. (1.3.1)

6/3/2025 7:02 AM Bug filed on "Screen Reader - NVDA - Labels and Instructions are Associated (1.3.1)"
Step no. Result Title
1. Failed

User navigates page with screen reader and for each input element verifies that any instructions, labels, and legends are associated with their fields and read correctly by the screen reader

Expected Result

All inputs in a form are programmatically associated with a corresponding descriptive label element. (1.3.1) Additional instructions or “help text” for the input are programmatically associated with the input element. (1.3.1) Short (2-3 word) formatting or helper instructions for the field should be included in the <label> element. (TR Ideal) Longer instructional "help text" for a form field must be associated to the field by setting the <input> aria-describedby attribute to the value of the help text element’s id attribute. If a form element is required and that cannot be assumed from page context, it either includes this information in the label, or has the "required" attribute in its tag. (1.3.1) Groups of form elements, such as radio buttons or checkboxes, are semantically associated with the group description. (1.3.1, 3.3.2)

Comments: 
Summary:
Users who rely on screen reader will find difficulty because help text is not narrating for the Items per page combo box.

(1.3.1) Additional instructions or “help text” for the input are programmatically associated with the input element. (1.3.1) Short (2-3 word) formatting or helper instructions for the field should be included in the <label> element. (TR Ideal) Longer instructional "help text" for a form field must be associated to the field by setting the <input> aria-describedby attribute to the value of the help text element’s id attribute. If a form element is required and that cannot be assumed from page context, it either includes this information in the label, or has the "required" attribute in its tag. (1.3.1) Groups of form elements, such as radio buttons or checkboxes, are semantically associated with the group description. (1.3.1, 3.3.2)

Users who rely on screen reader will find difficulty because label name is not defined for the filter combo box.

1. Failed

Set the viewport width to 1280 CSS pixels wide and 1024 CSS pixels tall, and gradually increase page zoom up to 400%. Check page functionality and readability at each zoom increment between 100% and 400%. On complex sites, user may need to refresh, or browse to the page with resizing already applied, in order for the resizing to properly apply.

Expected Result

Content can be zoomed up to 400% without overlap, loss of functionality, or use of horizontal scrolling (tables and graphics excluded). (1.4.10) -Solutions must be considered for fixed/floating content on mobile views ("Pinned" or "Sticky" elements often overlaps/hides content at higher zoom levels and may need to scroll as a result) Information can be reorganized and user interface components can adapt at mobile breakpoints, provided information is not lost. (1.4.10) Do not truncate content vital to the understanding or meaning of the page unless there is an accessible way to view that content in full. (1.4.10)

Title: 508: [Engagement Manager][Administration][1.3.1]: The error messages are not programmatically associated.
Description: Please see Repro Steps field for bug details.
Repro Steps:
Screen reader: NVDA

URL Tested: https://www.engagementmanager.thomsonreuters.com/

Test results:

6/3/2025 7:11 PM Bug filed on "Screen Reader - NVDA - Errors are Associated (1.3.1)"
Step no. Result Title
1. Failed

User triggers form errors with screen reader and confirms that any errors associated with fields are announced when navigating to that field

Expected Result

Form input errors are programmatically associated with their inputs, either by: (1.3.1) -Placing the error message inside the <label> element and use CSS to position and style it. -Associating the error to the field by adding aria-labelledby to the field element and pointing it to the field level error container ID (IMPORTANT: aria-labelledby needs to point to the field's label, helper text, and error message, ideally in that order). -Errors in grouped fields (checkboxes in a fieldset) are programmatically associated with the group, either by placing the error in the <legend> or including the aria-labelledby attribute. (1.3.1) The error state of a field can be programmatically determined, e.g., aria-invalid="true". (1.3.1, 4.1.2)

Comments: 

Summary:
The displayed error messages "Subject is required" is not programmatically associated with the form field. Screen Reader users will find difficulty in understanding the fields in error.

Browser: Chrome
Screen Reader: NVDA

URL: https://www.engagementmanager.thomsonreuters.com/

2. Login with your valid credentials (Email ID)
3. Engagement Manager page is displayed
4. Navigate to the Engagement name link in the table under Client name
5. Tab till "Administration" menu and press enter
6. Tab till "Add note" menu item and press enter
7. Add Note dialog is opened
8. Tab till required fields in the dialog
9. Ensure the error messages are programmatically associated with them.

The error messages of the form fields are not programmatically associated with them.

Expected Result:
The error messages of the form fields should be programmatically associated with them.

Run an automated color contrast check in axe or another tool if you haven't already, and manually validate the automated tool results if necessary, by using the TPGi Colour Contrast Analyser (CCA) or a similar manual color picker. 6/3/2025 8:01 PM Bug filed on "Screen Reader - NVDA - Labels and Instructions are Associated (1.3.1)"
Step no. Result Title
1. Failed

User navigates page with screen reader and for each input element verifies that any instructions, labels, and legends are associated with their fields and read correctly by the screen reader

Expected Result

All inputs in a form are programmatically associated with a corresponding descriptive label element. (1.3.1) Additional instructions or “help text” for the input are programmatically associated with the input element. Title: 508: [Engagement Manager][Add engagement][1.4.10]: Content is cut off or overlaps when page is zoomed to 400% (steps1, 2, 3, and 4)
Description: Please see Repro Steps field for bug details.
Repro Steps:
Screen reader: NVDA

URL Tested: Feature 2

Test results:

5/27/2025 6:38 PM Bug filed on "Responsive and Reflow - 400% Resize (1.4.10)"
Step no. Result Title
1. Failed

Set the viewport width to 1280 CSS pixels wide and 1024 CSS pixels tall, and gradually increase page zoom up to 400%. Check page functionality and readability at each zoom increment between 100% and 400%. On complex sites, user may need to refresh, or browse to the page with resizing already applied, in order for the resizing to properly apply.

Expected Result

Content can be zoomed up to 400% without overlap, loss of functionality, or use of horizontal scrolling (tables and graphics excluded). (1.4.10) -Solutions must be considered for fixed/floating content on mobile views ("Pinned" or "Sticky" elements often overlaps/hides content at higher zoom levels and may need to scroll as a result) Information can be reorganized and user interface components can adapt at mobile breakpoints, provided information is not lost. (1.4.10) Do not truncate content vital to the understanding or meaning of the page unless there is an accessible way to view that content in full. (1.4.10)

Comments:
Steps to reproduce:
  1. Open: 
    https://www.engagementmanager.thomsonreuters.com/Angular/#/Engagements
  2. Login with your firm's email or valid credentials.
  3. Navigate to and activate "Add New Engagement"
  4. Set the viewport width to 1280 CSS pixels wide and 1024 CSS pixels tall, and gradually increase page zoom up to 400%. 
  5. Navigate all the steps and note that info within tab controls for steps 4, 5, and 6 is cut off.
  6. Select a client and activate Next. In step 2, activate the "i" control. Note how the tooltip is cut off.
  7. In step 3 interact with form fields and note how they are cut off or overlap "Engagement type" and "PIC". Enter any name and select an engagement type.
  8. Activate "Next". Interact with the "Year end date" field note that inserted data is not displayed. Hover the "i" control. The tooltip is cut off. Select any "Vendor" and "Entity" note how the selected option is cut off and overlaps with the down chevron.
Actual result:
Content is cut off or overlaps.

Expected result: 
Content can be zoomed up to 400% without overlap, loss of functionality, or use of horizontal scrolling (tables and graphics excluded)

Screenshot-2025-05-27T18-37-29.217Z.png
Test Configuration: Demo AF
